MINISTER'S
FOREWORD
The Crisafulli Government is committed to protecting the environment by
boosting recycling rates and reducing litter to our environment. This commitment
will be delivered by working in partnership with councils and the waste industry
to explore opportunities for investment in cutting edge waste technologies which
reduce the impact on the environment and create jobs for Queenslanders.
There is huge potential for Queensland to Your input is invaluable to ensure the
unlock the economic opportunity that comes Queensland Waste Strategy puts in place
from reducing, reusing and recycling valuable support for businesses and Queenslanders
materials as much as possible. without adding additional costs and implements
practical measures to boost recycling and reduce
We want to reduce waste to landfill and impacts to the environment.
transition towards a waste free society.
We have an opportunity to work together We all have a role to play in progressing
to accelerate progress towards the ambitious opportunities for innovation to better reduce,
waste reduction targets that have been set. reuse and recycle and protect Queensland's
unique environment.
The Queensland Government plays an
important role in ensuring the community,
industry and stakeholders have the right
mechanisms and support in place to manage
waste and create new jobs for the future.
By increasing recycling rates and reducing
litter in our environment, we can protect
Queensland’s unique environment and
create safe and healthy communities.
ANDREW POWELL
This draft new Queensland Waste Strategy Minister for the Environment and Tourism and
2025–2030 sets out a long-term plan for waste Minister for Science and Innovation
reduction and recycling and how we will work
in partnership with industry, local and federal
governments, and our communities.
4 Queensland Waste Strategy 2025–2030 ⋅ Department of the Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation Queensland Waste Strategy 2025–2030 ⋅ Department of the Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation 5

INTRODUCTION
The draft new Queensland Waste Strategy is our key framework for reducing
waste, boosting recycling and supporting jobs. We’re developing a pragmatic
new Queensland Waste Strategy, not a one size fits all approach. We want to
ensure we have the right plan in place to boost Queensland’s recovery rates
and stimulate economic growth. Your feedback on key focus areas will help
us identify and leverage opportunities to divert waste from landfill.
Each year, Queensland produces close to Our draft new Queensland Waste Strategy sets
10 million tonnes of waste. Our vision is for the Queensland Government’s vision for waste
Queensland to adopt a more circular system, reduction and recycling and how we will work in
where products and materials are designed to partnership with industry and local and federal
minimise the creation of waste in the first place governments. It supports economic growth and
and they are used for as long as possible by environmental protection by directing the policy,
reusing, recycling, remanufacturing and regulatory and investment framework to facilitate
sharing resources. a more efficient and sustainable use of the
State’s resources.
For every three jobs in landfill,
there are nine jobs in recycling. The Queensland Government will continue
to work in partnership with industry, local
Businesses operating with a more circular model governments and the community to facilitate
support economic growth and create new revenue solutions that fit local contexts, acknowledging
opportunities in the areas of design, reuse, that everyone has a role to play in improving the
remanufacturing and materials innovation. The management of Queensland’s resources to
cycle involves collecting discarded materials, protect our environment.
sorting and separating them into material types,
and reprocessing them to create new products. Work with the Commonwealth Government and
other states and territories will continue to build

THE BENEFITS OF
REDUCING, REUSING
AND RECYCLING
Growing the economy
An estimated $210 billion dollar boost to Australia’s
economy could be gained from the development of
new products, industries and employment derived
from waste and recycling resources1.
Supporting jobs
For every 10,000 tonnes of waste that goes to landfill,
it is estimated that fewer than three jobs are supported,
but reusing or recycling that same waste is estimated to
generate more than nine jobs2.
Reducing cost of living
The average Australian household loses an estimated
$2,500 per year through food waste, with an overall cost
to the Australian economy of $36.6 billion per year3.
Reducing environmental impacts
Reducing reliance on landfill will reduce environmental
impacts such as odour and land contamination.
Reducing, reusing and recycling will also reduce litter
and impacts on our natural environment.
1 Source: CSIRO website - Advancing the Circular Economy - CSIRO
2 https://www.dcceew.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/waste-and-recycling-employment.pdf
3 Source: End Food Waste Australia - Food Waste in Australia - End Food Waste Australia » End Food Waste Australia
8 Queensland Waste Strategy 2025–2030 ⋅ Department of the Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation Queensland’s Waste Strategy 2025-2030 ⋅ Department of the Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation 9

MOVING TOWARDS A SOCIETY
THAT RECYCLES MORE
In Queensland, we want to ensure that:
• products and materials are used efficiently to minimise the amount of raw materials used
and volume of waste created
• waste that is produced can be recovered and beneficially used to make other products and
contribute to the economy
• products and materials keep circulating within the economy at their highest value for as
long as possible, through remanufacturing, reuse and recycling.
What does this look like?
Reduce Recycle
• the need for single-use items such as • waste is sorted into recyclable
plastic bags, coffee cups, and excess components to improve reuse
packaging is eliminated and recycling
• items are borrowed, rented, or shared • cutting edge technology for collection
rather than purchasing brand new and recycling of products is utilised and
innovation supported
• product design uses recycled materials,
reduces packaging and is designed for • markets are developed
recyclability as much as possible. for recycled products.

• items are repaired rather than purchasing • new jobs and industries are a
brand new created from reducing, reusing
and recycling materials
• product design allows for repair, reuse,
and recycling, and aims for efficient • increased economic
and safe disassembly at the end of the opportunities are created from
product's life. innovation in manufacturing
• more regional and remote
job opportunities are created by
growing recycling infrastructure.
WHAT WE NEED TO SUCCEED
Targeted investment into critical waste infrastructure
Partnerships between all levels of government and the private sector
The right policy settings and levers to encourage investment
10 Queensland Waste Strategy 2025–2030 ⋅ Department of the Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation Queensland Waste Strategy 2025–2030 ⋅ Department of the Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation 11

WASTE HIERARCHY
Reduce, reuse and recycle principles
are underpinned by what is known as a
waste hierarchy.
The waste hierarchy is a nationally
and globally accepted model for
managing waste.
The hierarchy is important because
it guides the order of preference for
managing resources. Avoided waste in
the first place is the priority. After that
comes options for reuse and recycling.
Energy from waste and landfill disposal
should be reserved for residual waste.
The waste hierarchy is also reflected
in the Waste Reduction and Recycling
Act 2011, helping support a consistent
regulatory framework.

achieve waste avoidance measures and outcomes?

OUR PROGRESS
WASTE AND
The Queensland Government publishes waste performance data each year by 31 December.
The 2023-2024 data indicates good progress in some areas, but poor progress in relation to
reducing municipal solid waste (household waste).
RECYCLING TARGETS
78 per cent reduction in interstate waste compared to 2018–2019.
Four out of nine targets are on track or have been surpassed.

ACTION PLANS
A list of priority materials and products list will be maintained on the department’s website, with the
objective of focusing resources on key products and addressing problem waste issues. This could
be through a priority product statement or through the development of more focused action plans.
Action plans aim to focus, accelerate and communicate initiatives including policies, legislation or
programs to improve the management of these products and materials where the requirement exists.
• Organic waste • Plastics • Tyres
• Batteries • Built environment • Textiles
(including construction
• Other e-wastes • Litter and illegal
and demolition waste)
(eg solar panels) dumping
16 Queensland Waste Strategy 2025–2030 ⋅ Department of the Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation Queensland Waste Strategy 2025–2030 ⋅ Department of the Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation 17

Photo credit Brisbane City Council
BATTERIES AND
FIRE RISKS
End-of-life batteries can be a real threat to people and property when disposed
of incorrectly. Batteries, particularly rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (found
in electronic devices, vapes, stick vacuums, electric bikes and scooters) can
significantly increase the risk of fires in bins, trucks, waste transfer stations
and landfills.
Queensland has experienced several The government has announced a three-point
fires at recycling facilities. action plan for immediate action to reduce
the risks from batteries. This includes:
Unsafe disposal of batteries has the potential
to shut down our essential services for long 1. providing $2 million in grants to support
periods of time, increase costs to councils councils in expanding their battery
and ratepayers and puts waste workers lives collection points at convenient locations,
at risk. including for problem batteries like those
found in vapes and e-scooters
2. working closely with the waste industry
on practical ways to reduce fire risks
to protect workers and essential waste
services
3. equipping Queenslanders with
information to make informed decisions
about safe battery disposal through
education and awareness initiatives.

AND PRINCIPLES Queensland will support national reforms and initiatives where it provides a
direct benefit to Queensland and does not increase costs for Queenslanders.
We are committed to working across jurisdictions to achieve the best
outcomes for Queensland.
Where it provides benefits to Queenslanders, we will work with

APPENDIX A APPENDIX A WASTE LEVY REVIEW
WASTE LEVY QUEENSLAND’S EXISTING
WASTE LEVY SETTINGS
The waste levy is payable on all waste in Queensland that is:
REVIEW
• disposed to a leviable waste disposal site (landfill) within the levy zone, or
• generated in a levy zone and disposed of to a landfill outside the levy zone.
A waste disposal site is a waste facility to which both of the following apply:
The draft new Queensland Waste Strategy is underpinned
• the operator of the facility is required to hold an environmental authority for the disposal
by the waste disposal levy which is administered through the
of waste at the facility (i.e. ERA 60 under the Environmental Protection Act 1994)
Waste Reduction and Recycling Act 2011 (WRR ACT).
• waste delivered to the facility sometimes includes waste that is subsequently disposed
of to landfill at the facility.
The waste levy aims to: A further review is proposed in
2025-2026 which would focus on:

regional zone (the remaining 27 local government areas in the levy zone). Regional and remote
recycling rates and incentivising recycling
• encourage waste avoidance local government areas are excluded from the levy zone.

ANNUAL PAYMENTS with the waste levy that need to be addressed?
TO LOCAL GOVERNMENTS
Local governments receive annual
payments to offset the direct costs of
the waste levy liability incurred on the
disposal of household and some other
municipal solid wastes. The amounts
for these payments, over a four-year
period are set out in Schedule 5 of
the Waste Reduction and Recycling
Regulation 2023.
